7.68.text:

As I read your

25.90.text:

34.89.text:
12 million times

40.40.text:
So we've got quite
an accomplished,

42.88.text:
well read individual

47.26.text:
"Getting Past No," and "The

53.04.text:
But that's just a small

57.14.text:
And I don't know if--

59.46.text:
I sent the link

61.65.text:

64.61.text:
But he's the co-founder

71.13.text:
And he's currently a

75.74.text:
But this is where it starts to

He's worked providing mediation

83.92.text:

92.73.text:

where he's actually

So later today when you

109.64.text:

113.99.text:
think back to this and you'll

123.39.text:
He's also won several

127.92.text: many, many times for his work.

129.63.text:
There were one or two that

He's won a Distinguished Service

138.32.text:
So in addition to

140.24.text:

in training them to learn how to

165.49.text:
And what I'm really

And after Bill speaks

178.17.text:
and presents to

179.99.text:
have a wide open

We have between 15 and 20

186.44.text:
here today, so after the

190.38.text:
If you'd really like one and
there isn't one left for you,

194.37.text:
just get in touch
with me afterwards

196.00.text:
and we'll get a few more
for those people who

209.22.text:
What I want to talk
with you this morning

210.93.text:
is really about
what I think is one

212.79.text:
of the more important, valuable,
useful skills that any of us

215.96.text:
can have in today's
challenging times,

217.79.text:
and that's a skill of
negotiation, of getting to yes,

221.33.text:
of trying to reach
agreement with others.

223.93.text:
And as I've been in
this field ever since I

226.19.text:
was a graduate
student up the way

228.26.text:
here at Harvard
many years ago, I've

231.72.text:
had kind of like a front
seat view on something

234.91.text:
that I call a revolution
that actually accompanies

240.68.text:
revolution of which
Google is a part, which

243.21.text:
is a more silent
revolution, but it's

246.83.text:
a revolution in the way in
which we as individuals,

252.31.text:
Because typically a
generation or two ago,

254.39.text:
the main way in
which people made

255.98.text:
decisions was people on the
top of the pyramids of power

259.60.text:
gave the orders, and
the people on the bottom

263.08.text:
And now thanks to the
information revolution,

265.31.text:
those pyramids of
power are starting

274.85.text:
And as that shifts, the form
of decision making shifts

277.93.text:
from vertical to
horizontal, and another name

280.40.text:
for horizontal decision making
is negotiation, is getting yes.

284.15.text:
So that to get our
jobs done nowadays,

286.50.text:
we're literally dependent on
dozens, hundreds, thousands

294.46.text:
If we want to get to yes with
them, we have to negotiate.

298.71.text:
So let me just actually
ask you, if you don't mind,

301.03.text:
a few quick questions about
your own negotiating experience.

306.34.text:
Because if you think about
it, what I'm interested in

309.59.text:
is what stops us
from getting the yes?

314.00.text:
So let me just ask you to
think about your own experience

317.69.text:
for a moment here and ask
yourself the question of, if I

321.02.text:
were to define negotiation
very simply and very broadly

323.75.text:
as trying to reach agreement
with someone-- you have

326.37.text:
some interests which
maybe you hold in common

328.60.text:
like an ongoing relationship
with a customer,

331.42.text:
and some interests which maybe
are in tension with each other,

334.21.text:
like you'd like to get more
money for your contract

337.61.text:
for Google, and maybe
they'd like to pay you less,

340.13.text:
who do you find
yourself negotiating

341.96.text:
with in the broad sense of the
term in the course of your day?

344.73.text:
Just if you wouldn't
mind just calling it out.

350.79.text:
OK, we'll start with
the hard ones there.

375.26.text: So it's at home, it's at work.

377.60.text:
Now if you were to kind of
just make a ballpark estimate

380.80.text:
of how much of your time
do you spend broadly

384.39.text:
speaking in the
course of your day,

385.85.text:
engaged in the process of back
and forth communication, trying

388.78.text:
to reach agreement with
your teenagers, your spouse,

391.21.text:
your colleagues, your clients,
your suppliers, your boss,

397.38.text:
the internal
partners, and so on?

399.15.text:
What percentage of
your time do you

400.61.text:
think it would be, what
fraction of the time if you

402.81.text:
had to give it a
certain percentage?

410.10.text: How many would agree with that?

413.70.text:
So we don't always think of
it formally as negotiation,

418.07.text:
but in the informal sense,
we're engaged in this process

421.00.text:
from the time we get up in
the morning with our spouse,

424.36.text:
teenagers, kids, and so on to
the time we go to bed at night.

427.76.text:
And so let me just ask you
a couple other questions.

431.27.text:
I mean, would you
say, maybe looking

438.24.text:
at the past, say, five or 10
years of your work career,

441.00.text:
would you say that
the amount of time

442.59.text:
that you spend negotiating,
has it stayed pretty steady?

446.14.text:
Does it go down
over time as you get

447.69.text:
maybe more authority
in your job?

454.23.text:
WILLIAM URY: How many
say it's going up?

457.10.text:
So that's the negotiation
revolution in form.

460.91.text:
And I've travelled
around the world,

462.41.text:
and every country around the
world I see this revolution

465.43.text:
taking place in the way in
which we make decisions.

474.48.text:
A little slower in Russia,
but even in Russia.

481.05.text:
Well, you know, I
used to go to Russia

482.80.text:
back in the days
of the Cold War.

484.99.text:
And even though change
has been slow sometimes,

490.82.text:
it's changed a lot
since those days.

492.47.text:
There's a lot more
negotiation going on.

494.14.text:
In fact, "Getting to Yes,"
I remember when it first

498.71.text:
came out, there were
some Russian friends

502.81.text:
who wanted to translate
it into Russian,

505.15.text:
but they thought
negotiation was subversive.

507.31.text:
They didn't want
to teach people how

508.81.text:
to negotiate because then they
would challenge authority.

512.63.text:
But now there are
Russian editions of it.

516.48.text:
So one thing that I think might
be useful just for the next,

520.86.text:
you know, we've got
this hour together here,

523.80.text:
is if you have in
mind at least one

525.56.text:
challenging negotiation that
you're currently facing,

528.42.text:
something, it might
be just for yourself.

531.29.text:
It might be with
your teenager or it

532.88.text:
might be with your
customer, it might

534.84.text:
be an internal negotiation
with a CMO, or whoever it is,

539.34.text:
have in mind some
challenging negotiation, OK?

543.65.text:
Everyone got at
least one in mind?

545.95.text:
So let me ask you a
quick question then

547.57.text: about the one you just selected.

550.30.text:
There are maybe two types of
negotiations we engage in,

552.86.text:
the internal negotiations
inside the organization

558.36.text:
and so on, and then there are
the external negotiations,

561.40.text:
let's say, with clients,
for example, or suppliers.

564.28.text:
How many of you, just
out of curiosity,

565.90.text:
have just selected an
external situation?

569.75.text:
How many of you selected
an internal situation?

574.16.text:
And just out of
curiosity, if you

576.97.text:
had to say which one was
harder, the negotiation inside

582.17.text:
or the negotiation
outside, if you

583.88.text:
had to just make a broad
generalization, which

585.80.text:
personally do you
find more challenging?

591.21.text:
WILLIAM URY: How many
would say external?

597.51.text:
I mean, obviously both
can be challenging.

599.27.text:
But the great majority
of hands go up

601.36.text:
on internal, which is
interesting that oftentimes we

604.84.text:
experience the more challenging
negotiations as being

608.31.text:
the ones with the people
with whom supposedly we're

610.43.text:
on the same team working for
the same mission, whatever,

612.76.text:
but those are often
more challenging.

616.22.text:
Well over the years, my
passion over the years

619.32.text:
has been helping people
get to yes, individuals,

622.84.text:
organizations, societies, as
Brian was mentioning, even

629.47.text:
And the thing that sort of
struck me over the years

632.42.text:
is when my colleagues and
I wrote "Getting to Yes,"

637.22.text:
the most frequent question
we got for a while was, yeah,

639.76.text:
but how do you get to
yes with the people who

641.02.text:
don't want to get
to yes, you know?

642.28.text:
How do you deal
with people who are

643.90.text:
kind of rigid and
they're intransigent

645.85.text:
or they're using dirty tricks,
or all kinds of things?

648.90.text:
So I kind of specialized
in that for a long time.

652.01.text:
In fact, my follow
on book was a book

653.71.text:
called "Getting Past No,"
which was negotiating

659.38.text:
But over the years I began to
realize that in fact, perhaps

665.12.text:
the most difficult
person we have

667.07.text:
to deal with in a negotiation,
in the process of getting

670.57.text:
to yes, be it with
our teenagers,

672.03.text:
our spouses, our
coworkers, or our clients,

675.57.text: is not what we think it is.

676.75.text:
It's not just the
difficult person

679.17.text:
on the other side of
the table, as difficult

683.07.text:
Actually the biggest
obstacle to us

684.73.text:
getting what we want in
negotiation, curiously enough,

690.09.text:
It's the person on
this side of the table.

692.34.text:
It's the person we
look at in the mirror.

695.19.text:
Because after all, what
could be more internal?

699.87.text:
It feels to me like the more
internal the negotiation goes,

703.88.text:
What could be more
internal than ourselves?

706.17.text:
And so our biggest
opponent actually,

708.11.text:
the person who's going to
give us the most trouble

710.19.text:
often is the person we're
looking at in the mirror.

713.18.text:
I think it was
Teddy Roosevelt who

714.60.text:
once said, if you
could kick in the pants

716.14.text:
the person who's going to give
you the most trouble that day,

718.75.text: you wouldn't sit for a month.

722.06.text:
And so to me, that
obstacle can also

729.76.text:
If we can turn our
own inner opponent,

732.44.text:
as it were, into
our biggest ally.

734.07.text:
And that's really the subject
of this book, my newest book,

738.10.text:
which is "Getting to Yes with
Yourself and Other Worthy

742.78.text:
And where it lies
is to me it lies

746.57.text:
in our very understandable,
very natural human tendency

752.34.text:
In other words, to
act without thinking.

754.02.text:
I mean, negotiation is supposed
to be goal oriented behavior.

757.07.text:
You're looking rationally
to advance your objective.

760.78.text:
But oftentimes our own emotions,
for example, get in the way.

765.98.text:
As Ambrose Bierce
one said, when angry,

769.36.text:
you will make the best
speech you will ever regret.

773.73.text: And it happens a lot these days.

777.46.text:
And so the first and most
important negotiation

779.96.text:
And I want to talk a
little bit about that,

781.75.text:
but then I don't want
to go too deep into this

784.20.text:
without really
drawing you out more

785.66.text:
and getting into
your own situations.

788.03.text:
But just to highlight a couple
of points here from this.

796.61.text:
of being able to get
to yes with yourself

801.62.text:
is the ability to step
back from the situation.

805.17.text:
And I like to use the
metaphor going to the balcony.

810.45.text:
with the other
person on a stage.

812.37.text:
Part of your mind goes to a
mental or emotional balcony

818.72.text:
a place of calm, of perspective,
of self-control, where you

822.46.text:
above all can keep
your eyes on the prize.

827.31.text:
And for example,
these days there's

831.03.text: so much going on in our lives.

833.94.text:
We get texts, we get
emails, we get calls.

836.41.text:
There's so much information
flooding in all the time.

839.52.text:
And let's imagine you get an
email, an internal message

845.73.text:
been left out of an
important decision.

850.41.text:
So it's very tempting to just
kind of compose a reply, right?

855.07.text:
And then you get
the satisfaction

856.68.text:
of hitting the Reply
button, but you don't just

859.24.text:
You hit the Reply
All button and then

861.08.text:
it goes to the
entire organization.

862.70.text:
And there's a button
on that screen

868.03.text:
sometimes, or at
least it used to be,

870.41.text:
which is the Save As
Draft button, you know?

873.28.text:
That's the button that
very rarely gets used.

875.61.text:
And you compose it, you
get it out of your system,

880.47.text:
And you do whatever
you-- everyone

882.38.text:
has their favorite techniques
for going to the balcony.

885.25.text:
They might be go for a workout,
go have a cup of coffee

892.38.text: Take a night to sleep on it.

893.97.text:
Just take a few
minutes by yourself.

896.09.text:
Whatever your technique is for
going to that balcony, you're

899.16.text:
going to come back, look at
that message, that email,

902.25.text:
and you're going to
say, wait a minute.

903.87.text:
Is this really going to advance
my interests in the situation?

907.98.text:
And you're going to
hit the Delete button,

910.11.text:
and then either going
to pick up the phone

911.86.text:
and call the person,
or even better

913.12.text:
get together with them
if you can do that.

915.02.text:
Because when you're going to
resolve a difference like that,

917.65.text:
it's much easier to do
that with more ability

920.92.text:
to communicate with
a voice, for example,

923.46.text: than it is through an email.

924.97.text:
Emails lend themselves very
much to miscommunication.

930.25.text:
but not so good for handling
delicate or possibly

936.72.text:
So that's kind of
going to the balcony.

938.70.text:
You know, if I think about
my own personal experience--

941.07.text:
Brian was asking me
to tell a story too

943.04.text:
about my own personal
experience-- some years ago,

945.22.text:
I was involved as a third party
in the country of Venezuela.

951.41.text:
And it was at a time when
Venezuela, there were,

955.14.text:
like, a million
people on the streets

956.95.text:
calling for the downfall
of the president, who

960.98.text:
And about a million
people on the streets

967.63.text:
that it might turn
into a civil war.

969.77.text:
And I had been asked
by President Carter

972.38.text:
to go down and meet with both
parties and talk to them.

975.69.text:
And anyway, I had a number
of meetings with both sides.

978.72.text:
I want to talk about
one particular meeting

982.68.text:
He liked to meet at night,
so we had made a meeting

985.53.text:
at the presidential
palace at 9:00 PM.

989.32.text: He was a little bit late.

992.16.text:
Finally at midnight
I'm ushered in

993.58.text:
to see the president expecting
to find him all alone.

996.37.text:
Instead I find him surrounded
by his entire cabinet.

1000.99.text:
And he kind pulls up a
seat, says, here Bill.

1006.06.text:
What do you think
of the situation.

1010.42.text:
And I said, you
know, Mr. President,

1011.92.text:
I've been talking to some
of your ministers here,

1013.59.text:
I've been talking
to the opposition.

1015.09.text:
And it seems to me we're
making some progress.

1019.37.text:
He said, what do
you mean, progress?

1024.32.text:
You're not seeing the dirty
tricks the other side,

1026.21.text:
those traitors on the
other side are up to?

1028.00.text:
He proceeded to get furious
and he leaned in very close

1030.86.text:
to my face and proceeded
to yell at me for, I'd say,

1037.06.text:
Now you put yourself in
my shoes for a moment.

1040.65.text:
I'm thinking, well,
hey, that's not true.

1044.17.text:
And I'm wanting
to defend myself.

1045.83.text:
But I was able to go to
the balcony for a moment.

1052.09.text:
that helped me go the
balcony was a friend of mine

1054.34.text:
a few months earlier
had said, you know Bill,

1056.37.text:
if you're ever in
a tough situation,

1057.89.text:
he said, pinch the
palm of your hand.

1062.10.text:
And I said, Arnon, why would
I pinch the palm of my hand?

1065.14.text:
And he said, well, because
that'll keep you alert.

1067.22.text:
And maybe it'll keep
you a little more alert.

1070.44.text:
So at that moment,
for whatever reason,

1072.08.text:
I remembered the pinch
the palm of my hand.

1073.87.text:
And because at
that mind, in just

1076.58.text:
in terms of thinking about
it, I was thinking, wow, two

1081.59.text:
years of work all down
the drain, you know?

1083.71.text: You go through all these things.

1085.12.text:
And I'm sure, tough
customer calls sometimes,

1088.45.text:
you can literally,
you know, you think

1090.39.text:
you might be losing that
important customer, and so on.

1094.93.text:
So at that moment I just was
able to go to the balcony,

1099.87.text:
Because if I had
reacted, I mean,

1101.26.text:
President Chavez was famous
for giving eight hour speeches.

1104.18.text:
I mean, the conversation
could go way off the rails.

1107.88.text:
And that might
have been the end.

1109.48.text:
But by not reacting, by
going to the balcony,

1113.71.text:
by listening instead, I was able
to listen, just kind of clear

1117.31.text:
my mind because I was
able to observe myself

1119.80.text:
from the balcony,
just note the thoughts

1121.74.text:
and the feelings that
are going through me.

1125.40.text:
Now let me pay attention
to President Chavez

1127.68.text:
and just give attention
to him and try

1129.26.text:
and figure out what
was going on for him.

1131.06.text:
I mean, why was
he yelling at me?

1133.09.text:
Was this some kind of show
for the cabinet and so on?

1137.52.text: What was irritating him so much?

1139.74.text:
And sure enough, by
just listening to them,

1144.18.text:
he could have gone on forever,
but since I wasn't reacting,

1147.78.text:
after about a half
an hour he started

1149.34.text:
to run a little
bit how the steam.

1152.32.text:
And then I saw, if you
just watch body language,

1154.57.text:
I saw his shoulders
sink a little bit.

1156.38.text:
And in a very weary tone
of voice he said to me,

1159.67.text: so Ury, what should I do?

1163.62.text:
That is the sound of
a human mind opening.

1166.82.text:
Before that, if
someone's angry with you,

1169.33.text:
like it's your spouse,
your teenager, or whatever,

1171.41.text:
it's very hard to use
reason with someone

1173.42.text:
who's in a highly
emotional state of mind.

1175.86.text:
It's like beating your
head against a stone wall.

1178.16.text:
But by listening,
he kind of went

1181.86.text:
into a different emotional
phase of kind of like, OK.

1185.48.text:
And I said, Mr. President,
this is December.

1192.08.text:
Last Christmas all the
festivities around the country

1196.09.text:
No one had any fun
because of this conflict.

1198.70.text:
Why don't you just
declare a truce?

1200.96.text:
Give everyone a chance to go
to the balcony for a few weeks.

1204.35.text:
Enjoy the family
with their holidays,

1206.03.text:
and maybe when they come
back in January everyone

1208.53.text:
will be in a better
mood to listen and see

1210.47.text: if we can make some progress.

1211.68.text:
He said, oh, that's
a great idea.

1213.31.text:
I'm going to propose
that in my next speech.

1215.73.text:
And then his mood had
completely shifted.

1217.44.text:
He said, you know,
and over Christmas, I

1220.18.text:
think I'd like you
to come with me

1221.66.text:
and actually see
around the country.

1223.92.text:
And then he said, for
a moment he said, wait.

1225.80.text:
If you're always
with me, maybe you

1227.57.text:
